posts.name: partials

posts.description: This is a great way to modularize your CSS and help keep things easier to maintain

posts.name: modules
posts.title: Modules
posts.description: You don’t have to write all your Sass in a single file

posts.name: mixins
posts.title: Mixins
posts.description: A mixin lets you make groups of CSS declarations that you want to reuse throughout your site

posts.name: extend
posts.title: Extend
posts.description: Using @extend lets you share a set of CSS properties from one selector to another

posts.name: operators
posts.title: Operators
posts.description: Sass has a handful of standard math operators like +, -, *, math.div(), and %

posts.name: syntax
posts.title: Syntax
posts.description: Sass supports two different syntaxes. Each one can load the other, so it’s up to you and your team which one to choose

posts.name: parsing-stylesheet
posts.title: Parsing a Stylesheet
posts.description: A Sass stylesheet is parsed from a sequence of Unicode code points. It’s parsed directly, without first being converted to a token stream

posts.name: structure-stylesheet
posts.title: Structure of a Stylesheet
posts.description: Just like CSS, most Sass stylesheets are mainly made up of style rules that contain property declarations. But Sass stylesheets have many more features that can exist alongside these

posts.name: comments
posts.title: Comments
posts.description: Comments defined using /* */ that are (usually) compiled to CSS, and comments defined using // that are not

posts.name: special-functions
posts.title: Special Functions
posts.description: CSS defines many functions, and most of them work just fine with Sass’s normal function syntax

posts.name: style-rules
posts.title: Style Rules
posts.description: Style rules are the foundation of Sass, just like they are for CSS. And they work the same way: you choose which elements to style with a selector, and declare properties that affect how those elements look

posts.name: property-declarations
posts.title: Property Declarations
posts.description: Property declarations define how elements that match a selector are styled. But Sass adds extra features to make them easier to write and to automate.

posts.name: parent-selector
posts.title: Parent Selector
posts.description: The parent selector, &, is a special selector invented by Sass that’s used in nested selectors to refer to the outer selector.
